project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h5. Issue Summary
 * When migrating from Cloud to Server, the Request Type icons are different and cause a lot of errors

h5. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Service Desk in Cloud
 # Create one or more Service Desk projects.
 # Create an XML Backup for Server
 # Restore the XML Backup on JIRA Server.
 # Go to the SD projects and see the Queues or the Request Types.

h5. Expected Behavior
 * The icons for the request types are shown correctly.

h5. Actual Behavior
 * There are several broken icons: !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail!
 * Each broken icon throws a logging error, flooding the log files pretty quickly with a File not found error:
{code:java}
2018-01-26 14:00:41,130 http-nio-8080-exec-22 ERROR      [c.a.j.web.servlet.InternalServerErrorServlet] {errorId=a375e86d-abab-4188-aa71-b262a5ddd0d2, interpretedMsg=, cause=java.io.IOException: File not found, stacktrace=java.io.IOException: File not found
        at com.atlassian.jira.avatar.AvatarManagerImpl.getAvatarInputStream(AvatarManagerImpl.java:388) [classes/:?]
        at com.atlassian.jira.avatar.AvatarManagerImpl.lambda$processAvatarData$0(AvatarManagerImpl.java:367) [classes/:?]{code}

h5. Cause
 * There are system Request Type icons in Cloud that don't exist in Server (select * from avatar where avatartype = 'SD_REQTYPE') Difference [^Request types Cloud vs server.xlsx]. When an XML backup is generated, the references to the icons and the issues that use them are include in the data. There are about double the icons in Cloud than in Server. Even though the missing icons are considered 'avatars', the request type icons are not included in the 'avatars' directory, possibly because the files are actually inside the *jira-servicedesk-xx.yy.zz.jar* file (at least on Server side), in the directory img/request-type-icons (you can find them extracting the content of the jar file with a compression tool), so when generating the Export file from Cloud, the avatars/icons for the request types are not include din the 'avatars' directory.

h5. Workaround
 * Use this SQL query to determine if any request types are using the incorrect icons:
{code}
SELECT p.pkey AS ProjectKey, p.pname AS ProjectName, vpf."NAME" AS RequestName, a.filename as RequestTypeIcon
FROM "AO_54307E_VIEWPORTFORM" vpf
JOIN "AO_54307E_VIEWPORT" vp ON vpf."VIEWPORT_ID" = vp."ID"JOIN project p ON vp."PROJECT_ID" = p.id
JOIN avatar a ON vpf."ICON_ID" = a.id
WHERE vpf."ICON_ID" IN (
        SELECT id
        FROM avatar
        WHERE avatartype = 'SD_REQTYPE'
        AND systemavatar = 1
        AND filename LIKE '%-v1.svg'
);
{code}
* If this query returns zero rows, that means the Icons from cloud are not in use. You can remove those queries with the following:
{code}
DELETE FROM avatar
WHERE avatartype = 'SD_REQTYPE'
AND systemavatar = 1
AND filename LIKE '%-v1.svg'
{code}
* After running the query above, you will need to manually insert new icons to the Request Type for it to work again.

(i) As always, ensure Jira has been shut down and that you have a full database backup before making changes to the database.
fields.summary: When migrating from Cloud to Server, the Request Type icons are different and cause a lot of errors

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
*The problem*
With a large number of goals, issue page load and update takes too long. 

*Root cause*
In case where the instance has an SLA with a lot of Goals set, the GoalMatcher takes too long finding goals using the TemporaryIndexProvider. Every time {{isMatcher}} is called, a Temporary index is created and searched to find the correct goal.

This is currently called from the following:
 - Completed goal calculation for improved rendering
 ({{GoalViewServiceImpl#getCompleteInformation}} -> {{GoalCalculationServiceImpl#getCalculatorFromTimeMetric}})

 - SlaDebug in calculating sla value
 ({{SlaDebugResource#getCalculatedSlaValue}})

 - Reconstruction service for each time metric
 ({{SlaReconstructionResource#recreateBrokenIssues}})

 - Restore ongoing goals
 ({{consistency task, create default issue for new project, issue moved}} -> {{MetricStateHistoryExtractorImpl#extractTimeMetricHistory}} -> {{SlaUpdateManager#restoreSla}})
 - Update sla
 ({{issue changed event, issue event, comment created event}} -> {{SlaUpdateManager#updateSla}})

This task is to move the overhead of creating a temporary index earlier to remove overhead of creation. Move it to before the goal loop in {{GoalMatcherImpl#getMatchingGoal}}.

Note: When an issue update event is fired, we update the slas for all metrics of that issue. For each time metric we find the matching goals. Investigate if it is possible to move Temporary index creation before the time metric loop. This would dramatically improve performance for large number of time metrics and goals, but may be problematic if the index gets too stale.
fields.summary: GoalMatcherImpl#isMatching takes too long using TemporaryIndexprovider

fields.description:
The release of JSD 3.10 has caused us considerable pain, especially for Project Configurator but the impact on ScriptRunner has been high too. Many of the classes we depend on changed for this release, and we cannot rely just on API classes because they do not give the functionality they need.

Project Configurator (PC) is a key part of Atlassian's Data Portability strategy, with PC providing ways to migrate and promote configuration between instances. We currently have three implementations of the JSD integration for PC to support Jira 7.0 to 7.7 and at the current rate we will need to add as much as one per Jira release which will lead to an unmaintainable mess.

What I'd like to do is start a conversation to get the functionality we need into an API with the same kinds of deprecation policies that other Atlassian APIs. If we don't have this then we will need to revisit support for JSD in the Data Portability strategy.

At App week we spoke to Lachlan Goodhew-Cook about this and we agreed that it would be a good thing to do. 

It would be good to include  [~lgoodhewcook], [~vsharma@atlassian.com], and [~gkaszkur@atlassian.com] in this discussion. We have also had discussions with Keshav Puttaswamy, Jakub Lazynski and Jakub Kurcek about Data Portability.

Please add the relavent people to the ticket and we can discuss.

For reference here are all the JSD classes we use:

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When we're configuring the customers notifications, there's no option to customize it according to request types. For instance, I'd like the notification regarding issue created to be sent for the request types X and Y, but not for Z.


h3. Suggest Solution
Add the ability to do so.


h3. Workaround
Use the automation rules from Service Desk for certain events such as:

When: Issue Created
If: Issue matches -> {{"Customer Request Type" = X}}
Then: Send email
fields.summary: Customize notifications per Request Type

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Warning message for using custom priorities cannot be dismissed by clicking on "Diese Warnung verwerfen / Dismiss this warning"

!screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
h3. Expected Results

After clicking on dismiss, the warning message should disappear.
h3. Actual Results

The warning message cannot be dismissed.
h3. Workaround
{panel}
*Note that multiple projects could be affected by this issue, so you might have to apply the same workaround to multiple projects*:
 # Ensure to make a backup of DB before making any changes to it.
 # Shutdown JIRA.
 # Run the following query in the database to determine if there is any duplicate rows corresponding to the warning message:
{code:java}
select * from "AO_54307E_CAPABILITY" where "CAPABILITY_NAME" like 'SD_PRIORITY_SCHEME_IN_USE%';
{code}

 # Let's assume that you got duplicate rows for a given project ID, as shown in the screenshot below (in this case, the project ID is 10000):
 !image-2018-01-22-17-38-56-455.png|thumbnail!
 # The resolution consists in removing all the duplicate rows with the highest ID. In the example below, there are 2 duplicate rows for the project ID 10000 with the IDs 4 and 5, so the 2 rows below need to be deleted. If you see duplicate rows for other projects, please delete them as well. *Note that the query below only applies to the example provided above. The IDs will likely be different in your instance.*
{code:java}
delete from "AO_54307E_CAPABILITY" where "ID" = '4'
delete from "AO_54307E_CAPABILITY" where "ID" = '5'
{code}

 # Start up JIRA and verify.{panel}
fields.summary: "Priority Scheme" warning for Service Desk cannot be dismissed
